Context:
Program Name: RPN Bridge to BScN
Code: S442
Credential: Ontario College Graduate Certificate
Method of Study: Full-time
Duration: 2 semesters
Starting Months: September
Domestic Tuition: $7,022.00 *
Centre: Health Sciences
School: Sally Horsfall Eaton School of Nursing
Location: Waterfront Campus
Experiential Learning: Clinical Placement
Admission Requirements: Graduated from a two-year diploma program in Ontario with a minimum 75% cumulative program average.
Program Description: The RPN Bridge to BScN bridging program provides registered practical nurses (RPNs) with the knowledge and skills necessary to enter Trent University's B.Sc.N. degree program offered on-site at George Brown’s Daphne Cockwell Centre for Health Sciences located at the Waterfront Campus in downtown Toronto.

* Domestic tuition is subject to change and may vary depending on the student's individual circumstances. It's recommended to check with the college for the most accurate and up-to-date information.

Context: The RPN Bridge program is offered through a full-time flexible delivery model and is delivered in a hybrid format that includes both in-class and online learning. The semesters are delivered consecutively, with semester 1 starting in September and semester 2 starting in January. Students will be expected to attend their clinical placement each week during semester 2 of the program. Clinical placements may take place in a simulated clinical environment or within a healthcare organization. Students who successfully complete the R.P.N. Bridge to B.Sc.N. Bridge program will be eligible to apply to Trent University’s post-bridge nursing degree program delivered on-site at George Brown College's Daphne Cockwell Centre for Health Sciences at Waterfront Campus. To be eligible for admission to Trent University’s Post-Bridge BScN Pathway, students must have met the Bridge program admission criteria and have graduated from the approved RPN Bridge to BScN (S442) certificate program with a minimum cumulative program average grade of 75 per cent. Public health recommends that people working with vulnerable communities be fully vaccinated against COVID-19, and clinical agency partners require students to be fully vaccinated against COVID-19 in order to complete clinical placements within their facilities. Students who are not vaccinated are at risk of not being able to complete their clinical placement course requirements.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2024/RPN Bridge to BScN Program (Postgraduate) S442 | George Brown College2024.txt

Context:
The Trent University offers a Post-Bridge B.Sc.N. program leading to an honours degree in Nursing (B.Sc.N.). Students must have a minimum cumulative program average grade of 75% and not less than 70% in any course of the Bridge program to be eligible for advanced standing credit. The program consists of 20 credits and normally takes five consecutive semesters (19 months) for full-time students or eight consecutive semesters for part-time students.

Required courses are spread over two semesters:

Semester 1:
- NURS 1093: Becoming an Ethical Practitioner
- NURS 1095: Nursing Informatics in the Health-Care Information Age
- NURS 1096: Introduction to Nursing Research
- NURS 1072: Critical Thinking to Scholarly Writing
- NURS 1074: Theoretical Foundations of Nursing
- NURS 1106: Health Assessment
- One University Elective

Semester 2:
- NURS 1101: Pathophysiology & Pharmacology
- NURS 1084: Family and Relational Inquiry
- NURS 1094: Transition to Clinical Leadership
- NURS 1102: Clinical Practice
- NURS 1103: Psychology – Adult Development
- One University Elective

Program Learning Outcomes:
The graduate will be able to:
1. Communicate effectively verbally and in writing, use interpersonal skills to assume a leadership role on the clinical team
2. Demonstrate novice-level scholarly writing
3. Collaborate with the interprofessional team
4. Integrate information standards, technology and information literacy tools to facilitate both client care and professional self-development
5. Demonstrate social responsibility and advocacy for individuals, families, groups, and communities in various practice situations and settings
6. Apply skills and competencies to facilitate professional accountability, collaboration, leadership, continuing competence, and the practice of nursing
7. Examine the basic language and goal of research and the implications of research findings for nursing practice
8. Demonstrate holistic, patient/family-centred care across the lifespan and continuum of care in various practice situations and settings.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2024/RPN Bridge to BScN Program (Postgraduate) S442 | George Brown College2024.txt

Context:
Program: The text does not provide any specific information about the program offered by the college beyond it being a Practical Nursing (PN) diploma program.

Tuition & Fees:
- Domestic Tuition: $7,022.00 for the first two semesters of programs starting in Fall 2023.
- International students are not eligible to apply for this program.
- Financial Assistance: The program is approved for OSAP funding.
- Fees are subject to change for programs starting in Fall 2024 and at later dates.
- Books are not included in the tuition fee and must be purchased separately by the student.

Admission Requirements:
- Applicants must be a Registered practical nurse (RPN) in good standing with the College of Nurses of Ontario and without practice restrictions.
- Graduation from a two-year community college Practical Nursing (PN) diploma program in Ontario with a minimum cumulative program average of 75 per cent and no failed or repeated courses.
- Submission of all post-secondary transcripts from Canadian and international educational institutions attended is required for academic performance review.
- Applicants with prior university or college study in fields outside of Practical Nursing must present a minimum combined grade point average (CGPA) of 2.33 (C+) and be considered “In Good Standing” with no failures in core prerequisite subjects to be considered.
- Applicants applying with international education must present a course-by-course evaluation from WES or ICAS, and where PASS/FAIL grades are the only grades available, a letter from the issuing academic institution must indicate a minimum score for PASS.
- Applicants with PASS/FAIL grades from out-of-province institutions must present a letter from the issuing academic institution to indicate a minimum passing grade.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2024/RPN Bridge to BScN Program (Postgraduate) S442 | George Brown College2024.txt

Context:
* Applicants from provinces other than Ontario must present a letter from their issuing academic institution indicating a minimum passing score.
* Applicants who have completed a Practical Nursing Certificate to Diploma upgrading program at a recognized community college in Ontario will be considered on an individual basis.
* Applicants with prior nursing studies in a Bachelor of Nursing or Bridging program will be considered by the admissions committee on a case-by-case basis, regardless of length of study or performance in a PN program.
* All applicants offered admission require approval of the admissions committee, which is comprised of representatives from Trent University and George Brown College.
* Applicants who have been absent from full-time formal Practical Nursing, Bridging or BScN education for a period of 10 years will be considered on a case-by-case basis.
* S442 Conditional Offers of Admission are subject to availability and may be stopped at any point in the admissions cycle at the discretion of the Admissions Committee.
* The program is open only to domestic applicants.
* Domestic students should apply through Ontario Colleges.
* Contact information for Sally Horsfall Eaton School of Nursing: Phone - 416-415-5000, ext. 2367, Email - nursing@georgebrown.ca.
* Additional related programs offered by George Brown College: Practical Nursing (PN) (S121), Bachelor of Science in Nursing (B.Sc.N.) (S118), Personal Support Worker Pathway to Practical Nursing (S119).
* Testimonial from a student named Anshumi Joshi, who completed PSW, Pathway program, Practical Nursing Program, Bridge to BScN program at George Brown College and is now in Trent University BScN program.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2024/RPN Bridge to BScN Program (Postgraduate) S442 | George Brown College2024.txt

Context: Anshumi Joshi is a student at George Brown College. She holds an Ontario College Certificate. Anshumi has had positive experiences working as a peer leader and tutor within the Student Success Program and Accessibility Services. She expresses gratitude for the support she has received from faculty and student services staff, and has made nursing friendships during her time at the college. Her educational journey at George Brown College spans from a PSW (Presidential Service Worker) to a BScN (Bachelor of Science in Nursing) student.
